repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Achieving food security, reducing
            poverty, moving up the value chain

abstracts.cdata!:
Agriculture is the backbone of the
            Rwandan economy - between 2006 and 2010 it accounted for 35
            percent of gross domestic product (GDP); 45 percent of
            export earnings, and according to the latest household
            survey of 2010-11, for 73 percent of employment. Constraints
            caused by population density, hilly terrain, and erosion
            make it a critical determinant of rural poverty. Since 2001
            Rwanda has worked closely with International Development
            Association (IDA) to achieve food security and increase
            agricultural productivity - food security was attained in
            2010 and between 2000-01 and 2010-11 poverty was reduced by
            about 14 percent. The Bank will continue to support the
            sector to address some of the key impediments to increased
            agricultural productivity including: a poor feeder roads
            network; lack of information on investment potential;
            prohibitive air freight costs; inadequately developed
            frameworks for quality certification; and a lack of
            post-harvest handling and storage facilities.

repnme.cdata!: Rwanda - First Rural Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Rural Sector
            Support Project (RSSP1) for Government of Rwanda (GoR) were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the importance
            of maintaining a tight focus on an agenda that is manageable
            given the capacity constraints under which the project
            operates. As initially designed and approved by the Board,
            RSSP1 included seven components spanning a wide range of
            activities. Early implementation experience revealed that
            the scope of the design was overly ambitious, and that the
            Government lacked the technical and institutional capacity
            needed to implement such a broad array of activities. The
            December 2005 restructuring successfully focused the Project
            on a core set of activities. The need to build capacity in
            the Project Support and Coordination Unit (PSCU) to ensure
            effective implementation of the four safeguards policies
            triggered by RSSP2, and the need for the Bank to assist the
            Borrower effectively on safeguards. RSSP was in early
            compliance with the environmental and social safeguards
            triggered at appraisal and was found to have strong
            environmental capacity in the PSCU, but general safeguards
            capacity was found to be low. In hindsight, the Bank team
            was slow to act, and should have informed GoR of the policy
            earlier. The policy has now been fully integrated in the
            current phase. The importance of a consistent, coherent and
            straightforward M&E system clearly articulated in the
            Project Appraisal Document (PAD), with indicators clearly
            connected to the Project Development Objectives (PDO). Over
            time, the streamlining of the results framework allowed the
            borrower to develop a workable process for collecting data
            and reporting on output and outcome indicators, which saved
            the situation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Sector Support Project will
            cover a period of 14 years which includes three phases.
            Phase I will focus on building the institutional and
            technical capacities needed to support the generation and
            adoption of efficient cropping and post-harvest technologies
            and hence launch the intensification process. Phase I
            includes seven components: The first component will empower
            beneficiary farmers to efficiently manage
            marshland/hill-side cropping and livestock activities and
            promote the adoption of improved soil, water and, fertility
            conservation techniques; and private operators to intervene
            in land and water infrastructure construction and
            maintenance. The integrated management of critical
            ecosystems component will strengthen the capacity of local
            communities to effectively manage critical ecosystems. The
            promotion of commercial and export agriculture component
            will develop export crop agriculture through facilitation of
            access to investment capital and strengthening of capacities
            of farmers and exporters. The fourth component will
            strengthen the capacities of agricultural research and
            extension systems. The fifth component will strengthen the
            capacities of local communities, private sector operators,
            farmers and other private sector operators, and water
            management infrastructure to develop small-scale
            infrastructure. The sixth component will lead to higher
            levels of off-farm employment and incomes. The last
            component will support project coordination.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Rural Sector Support Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Rural Sector Support Project for Rwanda, which
            rehabilitates marshland and hillside areas, supports
            agricultural services delivery systems and rural transport ,
            and promotes off-farm productive activities. Following are
            measures that mitigate anticipated adverse environmental
            impacts: Supplying guidelines for contractors and an
            environmental code of conduct and adopting good site
            practices will minimize disruption of hydrology and water
            quality. Watershed management, using green and organic
            manure, and increasing the efficiency of irrigation methods
            will reduce organic matter and shrinkage and soil
            acidification. Creating buffer zones, diversifying crops,
            and establishing a biodiversity conservation and
            agro-forestry program will diminish biodiversity loss.
            Regular monitoring of nitrogen and phosphorus contents of
            drainage water will alleviate changes in surface water
            quality. Strict supervision during construction, limiting
            the use of fire, and replanting will restore destroyed
            vegetation. Establishing buffer zones with vegetation to
            filter sediments and planting trees and grasses on hillsides
            will counter siltation. Using biological control agents such
            as fish will reduce mosquito larvae and snails and
            consequently reduce health risks and incidences of
            water-borne diseases. Monitoring the water table and
            controlling water speed will moderate changes in ground
            water level and quantity.
